## Does your browser support TTS service? First of all, we should know whether your browser support TTS service or not. Look at following table, `tts.js` can easily know the support of each speaker(type of each TTS service) we use:

browser_support_table

# Quick Demo

quick_demo

## Getting Started `TTSManager` is the manager `tts.js` use to handle its TTS services. It is initialized with several `Speaker` instances. ```javascript // Pass one or more speakers into manager var ttsmanager = new TTSManager([NativeSpeaker, BaiduSpeaker]); ``` Each `Speaker` instance represents each TTS service that `TTSManager` can use. `tts.js` provide several built-in TTS `Speakers`, and you can build your own `Speaker` class by just implementing a few functions and properties in order to be operated by `TTSManager`. Till now, `tts.js` provide these `Speaker`. When you get a `TTSManager` instance, the only thing you need to do is call the `.speak` function: ```javascript var str = $('.example-speak-input').val(); ttsmanager.speak(str, function() { console.log('speaking finish'); }); ``` **Example:**

example_speak

And `tts.js` can read sentences one by one, we call them as a 'book'. Use `.speakBook` function to read a book: ```javascript var strs = $('.example-speak-book span').map(function() { return $(this).html(); }); ttsmanager.speakBook(strs, function() { console.log('speaking finish'); }, { onChapterStart: function() { }, onChapterEnded: function() { } }); ``` **Example:**
